description: From Middle English rapyne, from Old French rapine, from Latin rapīna, from rapiō. Doublet of rape and ravine.

entries.meaning: The seizure of someone's property by force; pillage, plunder.
examples: men who were impelled to war quite as much by the desire of rapine as by the desire of glory

verbs.description: rapine (third-person singular simple present rapines, present participle rapining, simple past and past participle rapined)

examples: A Tyrant doth not only rapine his Subjects, but spoils and robs Churches.
